p:
To fully map the relationship between DENV genetic and antigenic evolution, we adapt a substitution-based model originally developed for influenza ( Neher et al., 2016). Conceptually, this model predicts titer values through three steps. First, we align E gene sequences from titered dengue viruses and catalog the amino acid mutations between each serum strain and test virus strain in our dataset. Next, we infer how much antigenic change is attributable to specific mutations by constructing a parsimonious model that links normalized antigenic distances to observed mutations. This assigns each mutation
m
an antigenic effect size,
d m
≥ 0
; forward and reverse mutations are assigned separate values of
d m
. With this in hand, we estimate the asymmetrical antigenic distance
D ^
i ⁢ j
between all pairs of sera and test viruses by summing over
d m
for all mutations observed between the serum and the test virus (Materials and methods, Equation 2).
